statement.text: Dimensional analysis provides a systematic method for deriving any Planck unit from fundamental constants. By expressing a desired physical quantity in terms of its dimensions [M, L, T] and matching these with combinations of fundamental constants (c, ℏ, G, k_B, ε₀), one can algebraically determine the unique exponents that yield the Planck scale for that quantity.
statement.formal: X ~ c^a · ℏ^b · G^d · k_B^e · ε₀^f where exponents are solved from dimensional equations

explanation.intuition: Dimensional analysis is like solving a puzzle: you know the dimensions of what you want (say, a length), and you have pieces (fundamental constants) each with their own dimensions. You combine the pieces with different powers until the dimensions match perfectly. For Planck units, this method systematically reveals how fundamental constants combine to create natural scales.
explanation.key_insight: The power of dimensional analysis is that it requires NO physics knowledge beyond the dimensions of constants - yet it uniquely determines Planck scales. This suggests these scales are fundamental to nature's structure, not arbitrary human choices.
explanation.technical_details: The method works by: (1) Writing the target quantity's dimensions in terms of [M, L, T, K, A], (2) Writing each fundamental constant's dimensions, (3) Setting up a system of linear equations equating exponents, (4) Solving for the exponents. The system is typically well-determined or over-determined, yielding unique solutions or consistency checks.
common_misconceptions: Dimensional analysis only gives order-of-magnitude estimates - FALSE: for Planck units, it gives exact algebraic relationships
You need to know physics to derive Planck units - FALSE: pure dimensional reasoning suffices
Any combination of constants is valid - FALSE: only combinations with consistent dimensions are physically meaningful

step_1.title: Express target quantity in dimensions
step_1.description: Write the physical quantity you want to derive in terms of fundamental dimensions [M, L, T, K, A]
step_1.example: For length: [X] = [L], For time: [X] = [T], For mass: [X] = [M]

step_2.title: List available fundamental constants with dimensions
step_2.description: Identify which fundamental constants are available and their dimensional formulas

step_3.title: Set up the ansatz
step_3.description: Assume the quantity has form X ~ c^a · ℏ^b · G^d · k_B^e · ε₀^f
step_3.note: For most Planck units, we only need c, ℏ, G (so e = f = 0)

step_5.title: Equate exponents for each dimension
step_5.description: Create system of equations by matching powers of M, L, T

step_6.title: Solve the system
step_6.description: Solve linear equations for unknowns a, b, d given target (α, β, γ)
step_6.method: Use substitution, elimination, or matrix methods

example_3_planck_mass.solution_step_4: From M: 1 = b - d = b - (-b) = 2b → b = 1/2

complete_table.description: All Planck units with their exponents

applications: Deriving natural units in any system
Finding characteristic scales in new theories

learning_objectives: Master the systematic dimensional analysis method for deriving Planck units
Set up and solve dimensional equations for arbitrary physical quantities
Understand why dimensional analysis uniquely determines Planck scales
Apply the technique to derive all standard Planck units
Develop intuition for combining fundamental constants
common_errors: Making sign errors in exponents (especially negative powers)
Forgetting to check that the solution is dimensionally consistent
Confusing dimensions with units (dimensions are abstract, units are specific)
Not recognizing that the method gives exact relationships, not approximations
physics_insights: Dimensional analysis alone determines Planck scales - no physics input beyond dimensions needed
The fact that ℏ, G, c combine uniquely suggests these scales are fundamental to nature
This method works for ANY combination of fundamental constants in ANY theory
Planck proposed these units in 1899 before quantum mechanics or relativity were fully developed
teaching_tips: Start with Planck length as it's most straightforward (3 equations, 3 unknowns)
Emphasize that exponents must be exact fractions, not approximations
Show verification: check that ℓₚ/c = tₚ dimensionally and numerically
Use the table to show patterns: notice energy and temperature differ only by k_B
